OCS announces FREE lunch for all students

Opelika City Schools is excited to announce that as of September 1, 2020 ALL school meals (breakfast and lunch) for ALL students will be served free of charge. Due to the pandemic, the USDA passed a waiver that provides free meals to all students through December 31, 2020 based on available USDA funds.

Any money in your student's account will remain in his/her account to be used after December. Meals for virtual students will continue to be distributed on Mondays from 10:00-11:00 a.m. at Jeter Primary School.

Parents, if you qualify for free or reduced lunch, please complete the application form at https://www.myschoolapps.com/Application . It is important that this form is completed prior to January 2021 to retain your status.

ABC for Students Internet Vouchers
OCS Parents--your student may be eligible to receive free internet access through the ABC for Students program.
Governor Kay Ivey has committed $100 million in CARES Act funding to deliver free internet to eligible K-12 students in their homes this fall. ABC for Students will provide free Internet access for eligible students who are enrolled in the National School Lunch Program through their schools and receive free or reduced lunch. This week, families will begin to receive letters with vouchers in the mail. The vouchers will cover equipment and service costs for high-speed Internet service through Dec 2020. Please visit abcstudents.org for more information on the program. To apply for free or reduced lunch visit https://www.myschoolapps.com/Application

http://children.alabama.gov/

Click "Online Pre-Registration Applications for the 2020-2021 School year"
Click on READ MORE.

Choose Lee County Opelika City Schools/Opelika High School as your school of choice.

Questions? Call the Opelika Pre-K office 334-741-5623

shared_text:
Opelika Quiz Bowl
February 23 at 3:18 AM ·

The quiz bowl teams competed today at Alabama Scholastic Competition Association State Championship at Hoover High School. The Middle School Team (7th and 8th Grade) finished 5th in the state. The team beat Smiths Station, Berry (Hoover), and Cullman before losing in the Quarterfinals to Monrovia. The elementary team (6th grade) finished 2nd in the state, beating West Smiths Station, East Elementary (Cullman), and Northside (Opelika) before losing in the finals to Discovery Middle (Bob Jones). Northside also competed in their very first tournament ever and finished 3rd in the state. The team beat Arab, St. Paul, and Williams Middle (Huntsville), losing to Opelika in the semifinals, and beating East Lawrence Middle in the consolation match. Anna Wood (Opelika) and Lucas Duncan (Northside) made the all state team as the number 2 and 3 scorer in the state. I’m proud of all the hard work from our Opelika kids, and it was a great day to be a Dawg! Opelika City SchoolsThe Opelika-Auburn NewsOpelika ObserverCity of Opelika, Al - City GovernmentElizabeth White

post_text: OCS Family: A quarry is proposed off Hwy 431 just outside of the Opelika city limits. The quarry would have a negative impact on the air quality close to many of our schools-especially Morris Avenue Intermediate School, Opelika High School, and Jeter Primary School. Our schools have students and athletes outside almost every day and we are worried about the increased number of particles in the air as a result of operating the quarry. We are asking those opposed to the quarry to send letters to ADEM expressing concern for our students and request a public hearing. The link below contains detailed contact information for ADEM. #stopthequarry

Opelika High Theatre Society presents Black Comedy January 23-26 at the Opelika Center for Performing Arts. Admission is $7 for students and $10 for adults at the door.

Synopsis: Struggling sculptor Brindsley Miller and his fiance, Carol, are having a party with the aim of impressing Carol's bombastic father, Colonel Melkett, and millionaire Georg Bamberger. They hope the two men might purchase some of Brindsley's sculptures. Without permission, they have borrowed the furniture and effects of their fussy neighbor, Harold, to make their own flat more presentable. Just before the guests arrive, the main fuse blows, plunging the flat into darkness. What follows is a frantic romp with unexpected visitors, mistaken identities, and surprises lurking in every dark corner! Only we, the audience, can see the action that ensues in the dark. As you might expect, the results are chaotic, disastrous “ and very funny, indeed! Synopsis copied from StageAgent.com
